title: Keep Pets Warm Indoors
description: Cold weather can be dangerous for pets. Keep them indoors as much as possible and provide a warm, cozy bed away from cold floors or drafts.
tips: Use thick blankets or heated pet pads for extra warmth.
Keep your pet’s bed off the cold floor and near warm areas.
Close windows and doors to block cold air drafts.
Dress small or short-haired pets in soft sweaters or jackets.
Never let pets sleep directly on cold tiles or concrete.
Provide an insulated shelter for outdoor pets if necessary.
Check the room temperature to ensure it’s comfortable for them.

title: Protect Paws from Ice and Salt
description: Snow, ice, and salt can damage your pet’s paw pads. Always protect their paws during winter walks.
tips: Use pet-safe boots to protect paws from ice and chemicals.
Trim the fur between paw pads to prevent ice buildup.
Wipe paws with a warm, damp cloth after outdoor walks.
Apply pet paw balm before heading outside.
Avoid walking on salted roads or icy sidewalks.
Check paws for cracks or irritation daily.
Dry their paws thoroughly to prevent infections.

title: Avoid Frostbite and Hypothermia
description: Never leave pets outside for long periods in freezing temperatures. Watch for early signs of frostbite or shivering.
tips: Limit outdoor time to just a few minutes during extreme cold.
Wrap your pet in a warm towel if they start shivering.
Check ears, paws, and tails for pale or bluish skin (signs of frostbite).
Never bathe your pet in cold water during winter.
Dry your pet completely if they get wet from snow.
Provide a cozy blanket immediately after walks.
Call a vet if your pet seems weak or disoriented from the cold.
